The Divine Warrior is a bastion of defense and an irresistible attacker. Created by uber-moderator Christian "Torias" Gillott, this character has been built to pound undead to dust. Her full plate heavy armour and tower shield make her suitably difficult to hit. On the other side of the equation, her longsword specialization and great cleave gives her mighty offensive capabilities. In addition, her prestige levels as a Champion of Torm, and her experience as a paladin, reward her with powerful divine buffs.

Background, Analysis and Comments by Author

Equipment
Longsword
Full Plate Mail
Tower Shield

Saving throws are most impressive as she is blessed with a +11 bonus from Divine Grace and a +13 bonus from Champion of Torm. She also receives +4 Will, +2 Fort, +1 Ref from feats. The Divine Warrior can memorize 2 first level paladin spells per day. They should ideally both be Bless Weapon to make undead very easy to deal with.

The astute player will notice, however, that the real power of the character is in her Divine feats.
Turn Undead: She has 20 uses of Turn Undead per day. The Turn Undead power itself is actually weak for this character, but the Turn Undead charges can be used for either:
Divine Might, +11 Divine Damage for 11 rounds
Divine Shield, +11 Dodge AC for 11 rounds

Divine Damage: This type of damage is rarely resisted by enemies, so it is helpful for dealing with enemies that have large amounts of damage reduction.

Divine Shield: Divine Shield offers a huge AC boost and can be a life saver when swamped by enemies.

Smite Evil: 3 times per day the character can use Smite Evil: +11 to attack, +160 to Damage -- save this combat power up to quickly take down major boss enemies. Evil dragons, demons, and devils will know true fear when confronted by the Divine Warrior.

Divine Wrath: Once per day the character can use Divine Wrath: +9 to Attack, Damage, and Saving Throws for 11 Rounds. This, when combined with Divine Might and Divine Shield, makes the character an incredible combatant who can quickly and safely destroy an overwhelmingly large force of enemies.

Lay On Hands: Once per day, the character can use Lay On Hands to channel 11 * 32 = 352 points of Positive energy that can be used for healing (making it just as good as the Heal spell) or for attacking an undead creature that is susceptible to Positive energy.

This character is even more powerful when she has access to magical equipment. The number one focus should be on items that boost Charisma. Every increase to the Charisma bonus results in improvements to:
Divine Grace saving throw bonus
Divine Might damage bonus and duration
Divine Shield AC bonus and duration
Smite Evil attack bonus
Divine Wrath duration
Lay on Hands magnitude
Turn Undead uses per day

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
This is a very interesting build to me. It's very similar to the type of builds I like to play (desesperately duty-burdened dogooders). However, I've got a question (not criticisms, since I can't make a powerful build to save my life), and an anotation.

First of all, why 8 levels of fighter? If we kept the fighter levels at 4 we can still get WP and switching those 4 extra levels for CoT will increase the sacred defense and the divne wrath bonuses. What do those fighter levels give that you can't get with CoT, plus some extra bonuses?

Also, having in mind playability from 1st level, I beleive that cleave and perhaps blind-fight are taken somewhat late. At lover levels I noticed that my characters get way less damage fighting mobs from cleave's extra attack, and depending on the module, you might want to take blind-fight earlier.

I managed to get my own "version2 on this build (I came with it myself before finding this one) that I might post on its own thread to get critiques and comments, if anyone is interested.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
My only thought on why 8 levels of Fighter rather than 4 is that, while a pre-epic split of Pally 6/ Fighter 4/ CoT 10 would give you an extra bonus feat (Knockdown?), you'd lose 2 bonus feats in epic levels. One might be acceptable - because CHA finishes on an odd number (33) and thus might as well be 32, freeing up a shift of Armor Skin to fill the general feat left open by the loss of a Great Charisma - but it's hard to see what else could go. As it stands, Epic Prowess has already been sacrificed, so...

On other issues, I'd be tempted to drop Great Cleave for Knockdown anyway. I find GC can be a thorough nuisance (though, of course, necessary if you're chasing Dev Crit), in that it can side-track you from attacking a mage/boss and end up wailing on an easy mob while the mage fries you. But others will like it, so a judgement call. Still, LoH, Strong Soul or Iron Will (the saves are astronomical is it is) could also be bounced for KD. And I agree about bringing Blind Fight and Cleave (much better than its big brother imho) in earlier.

I'd also lose 20 skill points from Heal and get another 10 cross-classed into Tumble for another 2 AC (then maybe take Epic Prowess instead of Armor Skin for +1AB and damage).

And I'd certainly be interested in your take, Pelagius.

On a different matter, you say you like the "duty-burdened dogooders" - have you ever played Aribeth's Redemption? It's specifically designed for such characters. There's a thread in the Modules sub-forum if you're interested, together with links to the downloads.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Guys, do not forget that these builds are from 2003-04 and thus over a decade old already. People were just beginning to explore the possibilities of the game engine back then.

That being said, there is absolutely no reason why this build should not be a (fighter 4/ paladin 6/ cot 30) with an AB of 37 and great smite 7 along with the best divine wrath possible (+13/+13) and still absolutely amazing saves. Many of us could do that easily but i think since Pelagius is interested in the concept of a holy warrior, he should do it and get the satisfaction out of it. Needless to say i am looking forward to your build Pelagius and a belated Welcome to the ECB! is in order.

The Lord of Terror - The Diablo Campaign, literally begs to be played with a build like this.

It is a high quality, classic hack and slash module that goes from 1st to about 27th level with challenging combat. You can find more information in the "modules" sub-section of this forum. From there you can continue with Sands of Fate till you reach level 40.

It transpires with Aribeth's Redemption that you can load any character (I know because I dropped one build in from Aielund and it worked, though the gear didn't move across), so no need to go through the OC again. It will assume you spared Aribeth's life in the OC, and romance blossoms...Just make sure they're of Good alignment (LG is best, but NG and LN work too), male (no girl-on-girl action), human, elf or half-elf, and between levels 16 and 18 (assuming you want the best results). There's a lot of talking in the first mod, which is also linear in nature. The second is better, but it really wakes up in the third. Fortunately, the third is twice as long as the other two combined. It finishes at about level 27, so you could still continue with Sands of Fate as Valerfor suggests.
